entry.title: Setting up your workstation
entry.content: This first guide will walk you through a step-by-step installation of the required tools to start developing applications on Symbol.
entry.summary: This first guide will walk you through a step-by-step installation of the required tools to start developing applications on Symbol.

entry.title: Creating an account
entry.content: Create a new Symbol account to start sending and receiving transactions.
entry.summary: Create a new Symbol account to start sending and receiving transactions.

entry.content: Get the public key and balance of an account.
entry.summary: Get the public key and balance of an account.

entry.title: Sending mosaics and messages between two accounts
entry.content: Define, sign, and announce a transfer transaction.

entry.title: Sending multiple transactions together
entry.content: Send transactions to different accounts at the same time, using aggregate transactions.
entry.summary: Send transactions to different accounts at the same time, using aggregate transactions.

entry.content: Learn about aggregate bonded transactions creating an escrow contract.
entry.summary: Learn about aggregate bonded transactions creating an escrow contract.

entry.title: Cosigning aggregate bonded transactions automatically
entry.content: Create a bot to cosign automatically transactions that require your account’s signature.
entry.summary: Create a bot to cosign automatically transactions that require your account’s signature.

entry.content: Tokenize an asset using mosaics.
entry.summary: Tokenize an asset using mosaics.

entry.content: This guide will show you how to setup a joint account.
entry.summary: This guide will show you how to setup a joint account.

entry.content: Get the block information given a height.

entry.content: Create a unique name to identify your assets.

entry.summary: This guide will show you how to add a new cosignatory to a multisig account.

entry.title: Modifying a multisig account min approval
entry.content: This guide will show you how to increase and decrease the minimum number of signatures needed to execute a multisig transaction.
entry.summary: This guide will show you how to increase and decrease the minimum number of signatures needed to execute a multisig transaction.

entry.title: Removing a signer from a multisig account
entry.content: This guide will show you how to remove a cosignatory from a multisig account.
entry.summary: This guide will show you how to remove a cosignatory from a multisig account.

entry.title: Atomic cross-chain swap between public and private chain
entry.content: Trade tokens between different blockchains without using an intermediary party in the process.

entry.content: Cosign aggregate transactions pending to be signed.

entry.title: Creating a multi-level multisig account
entry.content: This guide will show you how to connect multiple multisig accounts to achieve advanced on-chain authorization logic.
entry.summary: This guide will show you how to connect multiple multisig accounts to achieve advanced on-chain authorization logic.

entry.title: Creating a subnamespace
entry.content: Once you have a registered root namespace, you can create up to 3 levels of subnamespaces to organize your assets.
entry.summary: Once you have a registered root namespace, you can create up to 3 levels of subnamespaces to organize your assets.

entry.content: Check the number of asset units you have sent to an account.

entry.content: If a mosaic was created with the “Supply Mutable” property, you can make more tokens or reduce the total supply.
entry.summary: If a mosaic was created with the “Supply Mutable” property, you can make more tokens or reduce the total supply.

entry.title: Linking a namespace to a mosaic
entry.content: Alias an mosaic with a namespace so that others can reference it in a more friendly way when issuing transactions.
entry.summary: Alias an mosaic with a namespace so that others can reference it in a more friendly way when issuing transactions.

entry.title: Linking a namespace to an address
entry.content: Alias an address with a namespace so that others can reference the account in a more friendly way when issuing transactions.
entry.summary: Alias an address with a namespace so that others can reference the account in a more friendly way when issuing transactions.

entry.title: Migrating from NIS1 to Symbol
entry.content: With Symbol, most of the previously available NIS1 features have evolved. This document will help you upgrade your application’s previous NIS1 features to the newly available Symbol technology.
entry.summary: With Symbol, most of the previously available NIS1 features have evolved. This document will help you upgrade your application’s previous NIS1 features to the newly available Symbol technology.

entry.title: Non-custodial node setup

entry.title: Retrieving your XYM from a pre-launch opt-in
entry.content: This guide explains how to access the XYM (Symbol’s native currency) you were awarded if you enrolled in the opt-in process BEFORE Symbol launched (March 12, 2021).
entry.summary: This guide explains how to access the XYM (Symbol’s native currency) you were awarded if you enrolled in the opt-in process BEFORE Symbol launched (March 12, 2021).

entry.title: Retrieving your XYM from a post-launch opt-in

entry.summary: This guide explains how to enroll in the opt-in process once Symbol has launched (this is, after March 12, 2021).

entry.title: Retrieving the global mosaic supply
entry.content: Different values regarding the total supply of symbol.xym are available in real-time, through REST endpoints on any Symbol API node. Click on each endpoint below for an example.

entry.title: Common Hacks and Scams
entry.content: It should come as no surprise that cryptocurrency users are targeted by a wide variety of scammers, hackers, and thieves. While some attempts may come in familiar forms such as impersonation or misinformation, the digital nature of cryptocurrencies opens the door to a number of novel approaches. This page is intended to help you ensure the security of your assets by explaining a number of common scams and security considerations. This list is by no means comprehensive, and you are strongly encouraged to research the topic further for the sake of your wallet’s security.
entry.summary: It should come as no surprise that cryptocurrency users are targeted by a wide variety of scammers, hackers, and thieves. While some attempts may come in familiar forms such as impersonation or misinformation, the digital nature of cryptocurrencies opens the door to a number of novel approaches. This page is intended to help you ensure the security of your assets by explaining a number of common scams and security considerations. This list is by no means comprehensive, and you are strongly encouraged to research the topic further for the sake of your wallet’s security.

entry.title: How to use your Ledger device with Symbol Wallet
entry.content: The Ledger Nano S and X are hardware wallets that support multiple cryptocurrencies, including Symbol.
entry.summary: The Ledger Nano S and X are hardware wallets that support multiple cryptocurrencies, including Symbol.
